Award.AwardTitle: Secondary Ion Mass Spectrometry Methodology for Nanoparticles
Award.AbstractNarration: With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Schweikert at Texas A&M University and his group will develop an innovative methodology for the analysis of individual nanoparticles, NPs. The uniqueness of NPs, due to their functionalities not present in bulk size, is well documented. A nuanced understanding of their functionalities depends on their accurate characterization. Generally the analysis is done on a large number (ensemble) of NPs. However, there is likely some variation in the NP population and ensemble averaging can limit insight into the relationships between size, composition and chemical reactivity of NPs. This is especially the case for very small NPs, where minor changes in size, shape, and composition can significantly affect chemical reactivity. The research involves custom-built instrumentation and will focus on probing very small NPs (< 50 nanometers) one by one. Briefly, a NP is bombarded with an individual cluster of 400 gold atoms. The impact of such a "nanoprojectile" at hypervelocity (30 km/s) generates abundant ion emission from an area of ~10 nanometer in diameter. The ejecta from each impact are mass-analyzed and recorded individually. NPs representative of current nanomaterials research will come from laboratories in the US, UK, France and Australia. The new tools for investigating NPs will facilitate the development of efficacious and safe nano-scale materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this project was to develop novel methods for analyzing individual nanoparticles, NPs, in dimensions smaller than 50 nanometers.  Their chemical composition is typically determined on bulk amounts of NPs.  Yet, there is a critical loss of information when measurements are averaged over a large number of NPs.  For instance, NPs of natural and anthropogenic origin are inherently inhomogeneous in size and composition. 

We developed an original technique for analyzing NPs.  The NPs, dispersed on a substrate, are bombarded with “nanoprojectiles”, positively charged nanoparticles accelerated to hypervelocity (15-30 km/s).  The impact on a nano-object causes it’s partial or complete destruction with ejection of atoms, molecular fragments and molecules.  In this process, a fraction of the ejecta are ionized.  They can be identified by mass spectrometry.  The one-on-one bombardment is at the level of one projectile on one NP, with correlated ion detection.  This mode of operation requires custom-built instrumentation and dedicated software.  Briefly, bombardment is either with gold NPs, specifically Au4004+  (i.e. NPs containing 400 gold atoms and carrying 4 positive charges) or fullerenes: C601,2+.  As noted above, the nanoprojectiles are accelerated to hypervelocities.  The emitted ions are identified with time-of-flight mass spectrometry which can detect a wide range of isotopic to molecular masses. 

The completed project is the culmination of two decades of work funded by NSF grants.  In this last project we have increased the detection capability 10 to 100-fold and enhanced the ability to extract analytical information.  Our mode of bombardment which, again, occurs one nanoprojectile at a time, means we have a tool for probing nanospots and individual nanoparticles.  Some results are summarized below.

Ion ejection from NPs on 2D solids.  A key issue was to advance our understanding of the process of ion ejection due to impact of energetic nanoprojectiles.  Attention focused on the collision of nanoprojectiles with NPs deposited on graphene.  New observations about energy partitioning and ion emission from NPs on 2D solids have been documented. 

Counting atoms.  In a collaboration with scientists at UT-Austin, we developed the methodology for determining the number of gold atoms encapsulated in supramolecular assemblies.  Agglomerates of 55, 147 and 225 atoms of gold were measured quantitatively.  We further determined the sites within the supramolecular structure where the gold inclusions locate preferentially.  The ultra-small gold NPs are of interest as efficient catalysts for synthesis.

Fate of catalyst.  In collaboration with scientists at Academia Sinica, we have studies the fate of vitamin B12 molecules exposed to high temperatures.  This molecule is a possible replacement for platinum as a catalyst in fuel cells.  We could follow the dispersion of the catalytically active moiety of vitamin B12 and provide guidance for device optimization. 

Characterization of macromolecular architecture.  Novel brush macromolecules hold promise as organic light emitting diodes, OLEDs.  The critical issue is to determine at the nanoscale level that the molecules are assembled in a specific arrangement.  In a joint study with scientists at Texas A&M University and the Dow Chemical Company, we applied our nanoprojectile-SIMS technique to assess quantitatively the alignment and homogeneity of the macromolecular assemblies. 

Testing of molecular homogeneity.  We have validated that our innovative methodology can identify ultra-small NPs (3-5 nm in diameter) which have the same core composition and differ only in their surface molecular layer.  We could show the extent of mixing and segregation of such NPs.  There are currently no other techniques which can provide such information. 

The broader impacts of this project are many fold.  A postdoctoral fellow, five Ph.D. students and nine undergraduates received one-on-one training and gained experience in international team efforts with colleagues at UT-Austin, Dow Chemical Company, Academia Sinica, University of Louvain (Belgium), the Nuclear Physics Institute in Orsay (France), Lulea University of Technology (Sweden), and Jagiellonian University, Krakow (Poland).  Our collective efforts led to 13 refereed publications and 21 oral and poster presentations at regional, national and international meetings.  The impact of the NSF-sponsored work is documented with peer recognition:  an invited “critical insight” article in the Journal of the American Society for Mass Spectrometry and the 2015 Eastern Analytical Symposium Award to the PI for “outstanding contributions to mass spectrometry”.

The work completed is also relevant at the larger societal level.  It may be recalled that the effects of nanomaterials on human health remain largely misunderstood.  The novel technique developed at TAMU for molecular characterization at the nanoscale can contribute to an objective resolution of the benefits and drawbacks of nanomaterials.

 


Last Modified: 11/06/2017
Modified by: Emile A Schweikert
